div.p: Greetings. I have sent you, dear brother, my thoughts on the French alliance written down. I ask you to consider this favorably from me.
I know indeed that the situations of yours and ours are different.

Among us, it has never been possible until now to join in an alliance. If I could maintain this, I would consider myself to have rendered excellent service; if I could not, I would be forced to adopt other plans, which I would believe to be less harmful.
But you are among those who have always been allied with the king. It would be difficult and indeed impossible to persuade them otherwise.
Therefore, I did not send those thoughts of mine to instruct you on what to do among your people, but so that you might understand my judgment on this matter.
The French delegation, which is expected here tomorrow, is pressing the alliance very strongly.
My greatest desire is to depart from here and to see the Lord in the heavenly kingdom and to be with all the saints. ZÃ¼rich, September 1, 1564.
